questions.text: A 12-year-old male presents with complaints of recurrent loose stools with features of malabsorption & abdominal bloating. He is having less weight for age and less height for age. He is also found to be positive for HLA-DQ2 alleles. What will be the effective management?
questions.solution:
• 12-year-old male with malabsorption, bloating, low weight/height.
  • Findings: Positive HLA-DQ2 alleles.
  • Likely Diagnosis: Celiac disease
  • Management: Gluten-free diet (essential for symptom control and growth).

Key Takeaway:-

(Barley,Rye,Oats untill unless gluten free certified ,Wheat)BROW diet should be avoided in Celiac disease.

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child presented with loose stools. The child was unable to feed or drink, was lethargic and the skin pinch was going back very slowly. What is the degree of dehydration in this child, if any?
questions.solution:
In the given case scenario the child condition was Lethargic,Thirst status was unable to drink or feed & Skin pinch finding goes back very slowly.most probable diagnosis will be severe dehydration.

Key Takeaway:Dehydration assessment & management

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

choices.text: Effacement of foot process of podocytes on light microscopy
The disease is more commonly seen in adults

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with massive proteinuria and generalized edema. He was provisionally diagnosed as minimal change disease. What is true about this condition?
questions.solution:
Minimal change disease has an excellent response to corticosteroids, which is the hallmark of the disease. Most children with MCD will show significant improvement or remission of proteinuria with steroid therapy.

Other options:-

Option A - Non-selective proteinuria: MCD causes selective proteinuria

Option C - Effacement of foot processes on light microscopy: False. This is seen on electron microscopy, not light microscopy.

Option D - More common in adults: False. MCD is more common in children, not adults

Key Takeaway:- MCD(Minimal change disease)

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

choices.text: Stop breastfeeding and start HAART in the baby
Fresh stool sample examination for Giardia

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant born to HIV+ mother develops recurrent diarrhea. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
In infants born to HIV-positive mothers, HIV DNA or RNA testing (such as PCR) is needed to confirm infection, as maternal antibodies can give false positives. Recurrent diarrhea in this infant raises suspicion of HIV, making PCR the appropriate diagnostic step.

Other options:-

Option A -Stop breastfeeding and start HAART in the baby: Diagnosis should be confirmed before initiating treatment.

Option B -Fresh stool sample examination for Giardia: Useful if Giardia is suspected but does not address HIV diagnosis.

Option C -Do HIV antibody testing: Not recommended in infants under 18 months due to maternal antibody interference.

Key Takeaway :- Schedule of visits for HIV-exposed infants at an ICTC (Integrated Counseling and Testing Centre) or ART (Antiretroviral Therapy) center

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: A 10-month-old female infant was admitted to ICU with complaints of recurrent, intermittent jerky movements of limbs on the body. There are delayed milestones in the child. Her EEG revealed a pattern of hypsarrhythmia. What shall be the anti-epileptic therapy of choice?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of recurrent jerky movements, delayed milestones, and hypsarrhythmia on EEG suggests infantile spasms (West syndrome). The first-line treatment of Infantile spasms is ACTH.

Other options:-

Option B - Phenobarbitone: Used for other seizures, not effective for infantile spasms.

Option C - Phenytoin: Effective for tonic-clonic seizures, not for infantile spasms.

Option D - Levetiracetam: Used for various seizures, but not first-line for infantile spasms.

Key Takeaway:-Infantile spasm

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: What is the neonatal anomaly shown in this image?
questions.solution:
The image shows an exposed, red, moist structure on the lower abdomen, characteristic of bladder exstrophy, where the bladder is open and located outside the abdominal wall due to a developmental defect.

Other options:

Option A - Omphalocele: An abdominal wall defect at the umbilicus with organs covered by a membrane.

Option B - Gastroschisis: An abdominal wall defect usually to the right of the umbilicus, with exposed bowel not covered by a membrane.

Option C - Patent vitello-intestinal duct: A connection between the intestine and umbilicus, often with discharge from the umbilicus.

Anterior Abdominal wall defects

Key Takeaway:-Bladder Exstrophy

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: A neonate was found to have Serum TSH >100 IU/L on day 4 of life. What is the next investigation to be performed?
questions.solution:
An elevated serum TSH level greater than 100 IU/L in a neonate strongly suggests congenital hypothyroidism. The next step is typically a radionuclide scan, which helps identify the presence and location of thyroid tissue, such as thyroid agenesis, ectopic thyroid, or thyroid dysgenesis.

Other options:

Option B - Urinary iodine concentration: Not typically used to assess congenital hypothyroidism, as it's more relevant in iodine deficiency.

Option C - Serum TRAB estimation: Thyroid receptor antibodies (TRAB) are associated with autoimmune hyperthyroidism, not congenital hypothyroidism.

Option D - Anti-TPO Antibodies estimation: These are markers of autoimmune thyroid disease and are not useful in the neonatal setting for diagnosing congenital hypothyroidism.

Key Takeaway:-Congenital hypothyroidism

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: A child presented with anemia, mental retardation, bone pains and hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow biopsy showed "crumpled tissue paper" appearance. What is the enzyme deficiency producing this condition?
questions.solution:
Clinical presentation of anemia, mental retardation, bone pains, hepatosplenomegaly, and a "crumpled tissue paper" appearance on bone marrow biopsy slide finding in given image , is indicative of Gaucher disease. This condition is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme Glucocerebrosidase

Hexosaminidase-A: Deficiency causes Tay-Sachs disease (cherry-red spot, neurodegeneration) Iduronidate-2-sulphatase: Deficiency leads to Hunter syndrome (coarse features, joint stiffness) Glucose-6-Phosphatase: Deficiency causes Von Gierke disease (hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly)

Key Takeaway:-

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presented with palpable purpura on bilateral lower limbs. He also had arthralgia and intermittent severe abdominal pain, which was colicky in nature. There is a preceding history of upper respiratory tract infection 2 weeks prior. Which of the following drugs can be useful in this condition?
questions.solution:
• The presentation of palpable purpura on the lower limbs,arthralgia, and colicky abdominal pain following an upper respiratory infection is characteristic of Henoch-Schouml;nlein purpura (HSP), also known as IgA vasculitis.

Corticosteroids can be helpful in managing severe abdominal pain and other symptoms in HSP, although they do not prevent long-term complications.

  • Methotrexate, Cyclosporine and Azathioprine are generally not indicated for HSP and are used for other autoimmune conditions or more severe systemic vasculitis.

Key Takeaway:-HSP(Henoch-Schonlein purpura)

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: Which Vitamin Deficiency is associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
In above given picture Foamy whitish patch seen in temporal bulbar conjunctiva that is called bitot

spot.that characteristically seen in Vitamin A deficiency.

Bitot's spot is a specific sign for xerophthalmia. Other options

questions.text: Multiple fractures detected in antenatal USG are suggestive of which of the following diseases in fetus/neonate?
questions.solution:
Multiple fractures on antenatal ultrasound strongly suggest Osteogenesis imperfecta.

 

Other options:

Option B - Marfan Syndrome primarily affects connective tissues but does not typically cause multiple fractures.

Option C - Cretinism involves thyroid deficiency and affects growth but does not cause fractures.

Option D - Achondroplasia affects bone growth, leading to dwarfism, but does not cause multiple fractures in utero.

Key Takeaway:-

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: A neonate started on exclusive breastfeeds, has not passed urine since 24 hours after birth. What should be done?
questions.solution:
Failure to pass urine within 24 hours may indicate dehydration, renal issues, or urinary obstruction, It require admit in NICU for immediate evaluation and management.

Key Takeaway:-

possible Underlying causes for neonate not passing urine within 24 hours

Pre-Renal: Dehydration, hypovolemia (e.g., from sepsis). Renal: Acute kidney injury, congenital kidney anomalies.

Post-Renal: Urinary tract obstruction (e.g., posterior urethral valves). Other: Sepsis, maternal drug exposure (e.g., NSAIDs).

Management for a neonate not passing urine within 24 hours includes:

  1. NICU Admission for urgent evaluation.
  2. History & Examination to check for dehydration or abnormalities.
  3. Lab Tests: Electrolytes, BUN, creatinine, and possible urine analysis.
  4. Ultrasound to detect structural issues.
  5. IV Fluids if dehydration or hypovolemia is present.
  6. Specialist Consultation (nephrology/urology) if needed.

This approach helps identify and manage underlying causes promptly.

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

choices.text: Possibility of laryngotracheobronchitis should be considered
Flexible bronchoscopy is the procedure of choice.
Focal hyperinflation with reduced or absent breath sounds suggests foreign body aspiration
Hyperinflation is often produced by Ball-Valve Mechanism in complete obstruction due to foreign body

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child was playing and suddenly developed acute onset breathing difficulty. There is no history of any such symptom in the past or in the family. Chest X Ray showed unilateral hyperinflation of the right lung. What is correct?
questions.solution:
Option C is correct because Foreign body aspiration is common in young children .foreign body aspiration causes unilateral hyperinflation and reduced breath sounds due to a ball-valve mechanism, where a foreign body partially obstructs the airway, trapping air in the lung.

unilateral hyperinflation on chest X-ray often due to air trapping.

Other options

Option A - is incorrect as laryngotracheobronchitis (croup) typically presents with a barking cough and stridor rather than unilateral hyperinflation.

Option B -is incorrect because rigid bronchoscopy is preferred over flexible bronchoscopy for both diagnosis and removal of foreign bodies in children.

Option D- is incorrect as ball-valve mechanism occurs in partial obstruction, not complete obstruction.

Key Takeaway:-

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: A child with recurrent UTI was evaluated. His imaging findings are shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the VCUG findings where urine is refluxing backward into the ureters and reaching the pelvis of both kidneys, this is indeed suggestive of Bilateral Vesicoureteral Reflux (VUR)

Other options:-

Option A - Bladder Diverticula : Outpouchings in the bladder wall that cause urine stasis, promoting bacterial growth and recurrent UTIs.

Option B - Ectopic Kidney : Kidney in an abnormal location, potentially causing drainage issues and increased UTI risk.

Option D - Vesico-Colic Fistula : Abnormal connection between bladder and colon, allowing bacterial contamination from the colon, leading to recurrent UTIs. Imaging may show gas in the bladder.

Key Takeaway:-

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: An 11-month-old child presented with crying episodes. On examination, there was a tender palpable mass in the right lumbar region. His barium imaging is shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
11-month-old child, episodes of crying suggest abdominal pain, and a tender, palpable "sausage-shaped" mass in the right lumbar region aligns with typical findings in intussusception. The barium study shows a "coil-spring" appearance, a radiological hallmark of intussusception.

Key Takeaway:-Intussusception

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: A child with early exercise fatiguability presented to the OPD. The pediatrician suspected McArdle Disease. Which of the following enzymes will be deficient in this child?
questions.solution:
McArdle Disease involves a deficiency in muscle phosphorylase, which limits glycogen breakdown in muscles, causing early fatigue with exercise.

Other options:-

Option A - Glucose-6-phosphatase: Deficiency causes von Gierke disease (GSD I), leading to hypoglycemia and hepatomegaly.

Option B - Phosphofructokinase: Deficiency causes Tarui disease (GSD VII), resulting in exercise intolerance and hemolytic anemia.

Option D - Lysosomal Alpha-Glucosidase: Deficiency causes Pompe disease (GSD II), leading to muscle weakness and cardiomegaly.

Key Takeaway:-McArdle Disease(Glycogen Storage Disease Type V)

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

• Cystic Fibrosis: Autosomal recessive condition.

Other option:-

Option A - Achondroplasia: Autosomal dominant condition.

Option B - Treacher Collins Syndrome: Autosomal dominant condition

Option D - Osteogenesis Imperfecta: Can be autosomal dominant or autosomal recessive, with the most common form being dominant.

Key Takeaway:-



Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

choices.text: Next 5 years or till 18 years of age
Next 5 years or till 21 years of age
Next 5 years or till 40 years of age
Next 10 years or till 18 years of age

questions.text: An 11-year-old male child presents with fever, arthralgia and raised ESR. He has a history of febrile sore throat about 3 weeks back. His cardiac evaluation was found to be normal. What is the correct duration of antibiotic prophylaxis in this child?
questions.solution:
Based on the patient's recent history of a febrile sore throat, which may indicate a past Group A Streptococcus (GAS) infection, and the clinical findings of:

  • Major Criteria (in given scenario):
    • Migratory arthritis
  • Minor Criteria (in given scenario):
    • Fever
    • Arthralgia
    • Elevated ESR (Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate)

This clinical presentation meets the criteria for a diagnosis of Acute rheumatic fever (ARF) as per the modified Jones criteria.Normal cardiac evaluation suggests no carditis, which affects the duration of prophylaxis

Duration of Antibody prophylaxis according cardiac condition in ARF case:-

Key Takeaway:-ARF(Acute Rheumatic Fever)

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

choices.text: Early diagnosis and therapy shows excellent prognosis

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child has a history of frequent falls, difficulty in walking and in getting up from sitting position. His muscle biopsy findings are shown. What is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The child's symptoms-frequent falls, difficulty walking, and trouble rising from a sitting position

- along with the muscle biopsy findings, are suggestive of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).

Labelled muscle Biopsy findings of Duchene Muscular Dystrophy

Key Takeaway:-

DUCHENE MUSCULAR DYSTROPHY(DMD)

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric
